so first I thought I'd start with the hardware since most people have not really seen glass or played with too much this is something that I didn't

interesting sensor kind of in the inside which looks at your eye and tracks it um
Google hasn't really officially said what they're using it for there was one open source project which kind of hacked

the middle which is just gives you the time and okay glass so the way you interact with this is It's a pure voice
card so you say Okay Glass search for x or call Y person and from here you can
do all of the voice commands you want that kind of integrate mostly with search and other Google products like Google Hangouts um as soon as you're on
the screen however you can swipe right and on the right side you'll see a list of all of the notifications from the
apps you um you've subscribed to and um these will just be the newest to the oldest it's kind of an infinite list
it'll just go on until the last one um I think Google limits this to seven days worth of notifications but it's not very
clear and so the newest ones at front so generally when you turn on glass you'd kind of check for the newest couple
notifications until you got where you sto last time and that's it you're kind of updated on what's happening however
an interesting part is that from the okay glass card if you swipe the other way you get a list of pinned cards so
these are cards that the user explicitly has decided are important to them and they want always to be there so that
they don't get swallowed up by a list of new notifications that might come in um come in front so an app uh so an example
pin card might be something like the weather which just kind of updates automatically when stuff changes so the user always wants easy access to that to
see you know the weather so that's something that they might pin and so pinnable cards is a feature Google
allows in their API that allows users to pin your card and from there you generally use it to make updates or you
know use it to do things like I want to send a new tweet so go to this card and send a new
tweet so um uh notification cards come in a lot of shapes and sizes I mean
they're all in the same 640 by 360 bucks but they um they look a lot very
different so this is Twitter which is just exactly as you'd expect this is kind of what it looks like on the website this is what it looks like in
its mobile app and now this is look what it looks like on Google Glass the New York Times though kind of chose a
different approach so they have this pretty card with the picture on the top you click on that and you get a list of
stories um and you just can navigate through all the stories by swiping left or right uh the stories are on this um
the second row and from any of the stories you can click on them to read them out loud and what New York Times
has done as has um they put a longer snippet so they can maybe show the title and maybe a couple sentences in the card
itself because it's so small but they say um you know here's longer text that would be read aloud if the user so
interested um so now moving on to the API so the base um the base object in
the mirror API then is the timeline it's a timeline card which has some display content um developers can choose if
that's just text which Google auto resizes to fit in the card or they can just have arbitrary HTML arbitraries in
quotes because Google is a very strict list of tags that are allowed and not allowed there's no JavaScript allowed um
and they have a limited you know very small size but you still have a lot of css3 options kind of just within um the
confines of the glass um glass mirror API proper but in addition to just kind
of supplying this HTML string which is just rendered on the mirror um on your
glassware um you get these a lot of interesting interaction options so one is display time so every card in um
every card has a date like a created at type date but you can actually specify when a card should be displayed so let's
say that you have a an alert happening or some to-do item happening in 10 minutes you can say the display time is
now plus 10 minutes and it would actually that card would always be in the front of your notifications until 10
minutes past and after that it would kind of start filtering back based on other notifications that pop up in front of it um you can also specify speakable
text so that's texts that you want to be read out loud um with the card since a lot of times in most content heavy apps
will see this you can't really fit most of the content you want on the little screen so you'll want to have some way
of extending that content be it you know letting the user email to themselves or just being able to read it out loud um
there's also the option of bundling cards which is kind of interesting so a lot of times you might feel confined um
very confined with just a small um card but you can actually have a card that links to a list of other cards which you
can then swipe through so you kind of saw that New York times where they have a picture card and clicking on that picture card gives another list of
stories from New York Times so these are called bundles and they're one nested list of
cards so one of the more interesting parts that kind of separates Google Glass from let's say like an apple push
notification Android push notification is that you can interact with it so Google has something called menu items
which are just you can specify zero or more menu items which is just a way to interact with it so Google has some
built in like a reply which will actually let you talk to that card and it will transcribe the text and send it
back to the server um you can delete a card read it out loud pin it if you want but you can also create your own custom
actions on cards so you know Twitter might have a tweet action um New York Times has um you know could potentially
have like an email to me action if I'm interested in that um story so all you need for these is kind of a uid that
your server could recognize plus a name and an image uh Google's also kind of started um testing out States so you
know default pending confirmed and remove when selected but these are kind of still new we haven't had a chance too
much of a chance to play with it and Google just hasn't have documentation on these yet but I think they're really evolving kind of how you interact with
it and making it more complex and more um natural for the ways that you'd normally see on a website where you know
retweet might be toggled as retweeted after you retweeted a tweet timeline items can also have
attachments so these are videos images so an example is you might have an app that shares an image with somebody else
in that case that timeline card would just have an attachment which is an image or video the other base object in Google
Glass is location so these are pretty typical they give you the latitude longitude and um accuracy plus the
address and display name if possible and these are kind of interesting because you can not only get the location of a
user if they choose to Shar it with you but you can subscribe to Google and Google will actually ping you when a user moves um at some frequency
and you can also check you know where things like timeline items were created so you can see where um let's say a
photo was taken and perhaps kind of um react accordingly on your back
end so um the way to kind of listen now because you have um these all these
actions you need to subscribe to Google um by giving them a URL and Google will
just ping your url when a user does something to a card so they these are called subscriptions in Google's U
Mirror part and they're really just callback hooks so what you provide to Google is just
you know I want to create a subscription for a user so an auit in user so I
create a subscription you pass in a user token which is just anything you want presumably like the database ID for that

interacts with one of your cards Google will just ping your server saying user X did actions you know ABC to this
specific card and you know your server can react accordingly what's interesting is that they kind of batch these all
together a lot of times because the mirror um or glass rather can be used without internet access so um you get
like an array of actions that the user has done since they last synced up with the glass um from a development perspective
this is kind of interesting because one you have to create a new subscription per User it's not something you set per
